title: How to Decide Whether It Is Safe to Escape During a Fire

steps.headline: Plan your escape route ahead of time.
steps.description: Fire spreads quickly, and there may be no time during a fire to figure out an escape route. If bedrooms are on the second floor, be sure an escape ladder is near the window in each room. Designate 2 escape routes out of each room.

steps.headline: Practice your escape plan and safety rules with children often.
steps.description: When you prepare children, they are generally less frightened and can better remember what you taught them. Walk your children through each escape route. Have them practice opening doors and pulling up windows to be certain they can easily handle these tasks. If you have older children with bedrooms on the second floor, have them practice exiting safely through the window using the escape ladder.

steps.headline: Test your escape plan to be sure it works well.
Make sure the last person leaving each room closes the door after exiting.
steps.description: This will help to slow the fire, giving family members a little extra time to get out safely.

steps.headline: Choose a safe place outside the home where family members can meet.
steps.description: This can be a neighbor's front yard, your mailbox or another safe location.

methods.name: Decide Whether It Is Safe to Escape Using Plan 1

steps.headline: Look for signs of smoke coming through the door cracks or under the door.
steps.description: If you see smoke, don't open the door.

steps.headline: Feel the closed door.
steps.description: Place your hands at the top of the door and move them down the entire length of the door to see whether it feels hot. If the door is hot to the touch, do not open it. Touch the doorknob to find out whether it's hot. If you don't feel any heat, it may be safe to escape.

steps.headline: Get down close to the floor and open the door a crack.
steps.description: Look for signs of smoke and flames. If you see them, close the door and check your second escape route. If the way is clear, you can leave.

steps.headline: Move quickly through the house, using the fastest, safest route out.
steps.description: If you encounter smoke on your route out of the house but do not see flames, crawl on your hands and knees, staying below the smoke, as you make your way out of the house. If you encounter flames, you may need to go through another room to exit the house. Always test the doors and look for signs of fire before moving from one room to another.

steps.headline: Report to the designated meeting place outside the home, check to see whether all family members are safely out and call the emergency response number.

methods.name: Determine Whether Plan 2 Will Work When Plan 1 Won't

steps.headline: Remain calm.
steps.description: When family members are all on the second floor and you cannot use the stairway but the hall is clear, get all family members in the room that is easiest to escape from.

steps.headline: Open the window, which should be your second escape route.
steps.description: If you can safely exit through it, do so using your escape ladder. Always send children down first. If you do not have an escape ladder, pass the children down to safety first. Adults and older children can lower themselves to arm's length and drop.

steps.headline: Dial the emergency response number to report the fire once everyone is out of the house safely.

methods.name: Exercise Plan 3 When It Is Not Safe to Escape

steps.headline: Seal yourself and family members in the room when you are unable to get out safely.
steps.description: Use a roll of duct tape or stuff towels, blankets or sheets under the door and in the cracks of the door to keep the smoke out. Cover all the air vents and heat units to prevent the smoke from entering the room.

steps.headline: Call the emergency response number or the fire department directly.
steps.description: Provide the exact address of the fire. Tell the emergency response operator how many people are inside the burning house and the exact location. This should include whether you are on the first or second floor and in the back, side or front of the house.

steps.headline: Yell and signal for help, if you don't have a telephone.
steps.description: Wave something out the window to attract attention or shine a flashlight to alert help.

steps.headline: Stay on the floor near the window until help arrives.
steps.description: Smoke and heat rise, so be sure everyone stays low.

text: Be Prepared Plan your escape route ahead of time. Fire spreads quickly, and there may be no time during a fire to figure out an escape route. If bedrooms are on the second floor, be sure an escape ladder is near the window in each room. Designate 2 escape routes out of each room. Practice your escape plan and safety rules with children often. When you prepare children, they are generally less frightened and can better remember what you taught them. Walk your children through each escape route. Have them practice opening doors and pulling up windows to be certain they can easily handle these tasks. If you have older children with bedrooms on the second floor, have them practice exiting safely through the window using the escape ladder. Test your escape plan to be sure it works well.  Make sure the last person leaving each room closes the door after exiting. This will help to slow the fire, giving family members a little extra time to get out safely. Choose a safe place outside the home where family members can meet. This can be a neighbor's front yard, your mailbox or another safe location. Decide Whether It Is Safe to Escape Using Plan 1 Look for signs of smoke coming through the door cracks or under the door. If you see smoke, don't open the door. Feel the closed door. Place your hands at the top of the door and move them down the entire length of the door to see whether it feels hot. If the door is hot to the touch, do not open it. Touch the doorknob to find out whether it's hot. If you don't feel any heat, it may be safe to escape. Get down close to the floor and open the door a crack. Look for signs of smoke and flames. If you see them, close the door and check your second escape route. If the way is clear, you can leave. Move quickly through the house, using the fastest, safest route out. If you encounter smoke on your route out of the house but do not see flames, crawl on your hands and knees, staying below the smoke, as you make your way out of the house. If you encounter flames, you may need to go through another room to exit the house. Always test the doors and look for signs of fire before moving from one room to another. Report to the designated meeting place outside the home, check to see whether all family members are safely out and call the emergency response number.  Determine Whether Plan 2 Will Work When Plan 1 Won't Remain calm. When family members are all on the second floor and you cannot use the stairway but the hall is clear, get all family members in the room that is easiest to escape from. Open the window, which should be your second escape route. If you can safely exit through it, do so using your escape ladder. Always send children down first. If you do not have an escape ladder, pass the children down to safety first. Adults and older children can lower themselves to arm's length and drop. Dial the emergency response number to report the fire once everyone is out of the house safely.  Exercise Plan 3 When It Is Not Safe to Escape Seal yourself and family members in the room when you are unable to get out safely. Use a roll of duct tape or stuff towels, blankets or sheets under the door and in the cracks of the door to keep the smoke out. Cover all the air vents and heat units to prevent the smoke from entering the room. Call the emergency response number or the fire department directly. Provide the exact address of the fire. Tell the emergency response operator how many people are inside the burning house and the exact location. This should include whether you are on the first or second floor and in the back, side or front of the house. Yell and signal for help, if you don't have a telephone. Wave something out the window to attract attention or shine a flashlight to alert help. Stay on the floor near the window until help arrives. Smoke and heat rise, so be sure everyone stays low.
